title: You Already Know (song)
text:
"You Already Know" is a song recorded by American singer <a href="Fergie%20%28singer%29">Fergie</a>, featuring guest vocals from Trinidadian-American rapper <a href="Nicki%20Minaj">Nicki Minaj</a>. It was released on August 25, 2017, alongside promotional single "<a href="Hungry%20%28Fergie%20song%29">Hungry</a>" as the fourth single from Fergie's second <a href="studio%20album">studio album</a>, "<a href="Double%20Dutchess">Double Dutchess</a>" (2017), the same day the album was made available for pre-order. "You Already Know" impacted mainstream and rhythmic radio on September 12, 2017. As of September 2017, "You Already Know" moved almost 56,600 copies in the United States according to <a href="Nielsen%20SoundScan">Nielsen SoundScan</a>.
Background.
"You Already Know" has been described as a song with 1990s <a href="House%20music">house</a> influences. It samples "<a href="It%20Takes%20Two%20%28Rob%20Base%20%26amp%3B%20DJ%20E-Z%20Rock%20song%29">It Takes Two</a>" by <a href="Rob%20Base%20and%20DJ%20E-Z%20Rock">Rob Base and DJ E-Z Rock</a>, which in turn samples the <a href="Lyn%20Collins">Lyn Collins</a> 1972 song "<a href="Think%20%28About%20It%29">Think (About It)</a>". Prior to the song's release, a lyric about Minaj's ex-boyfriend <a href="Meek%20Mill">Meek Mill</a>, was changed following their breakup in January 2017. The single was written by Fergie and Minaj, with <a href="will.i.am">will.i.am</a> handling the song's production. Fergie first teased the collaboration in a radio interview in late 2014 while promoting "<a href="L.A.%20Love%20%28La%20La%29">L.A. Love (La La)</a>". The song was performed live for the first time on <a href="Rock%20in%20Rio">Rock in Rio</a> <a href="Lisboa">Lisboa</a> on May 20, 2016.
Fergie spoke about the song, saying:
Critical reception.
Jordan Miller of "Breathe Heavy" reacted positively towards the song, calling it "fresh to death". In particular he praised Minaj's verse. <a href="Stereogum">Stereogum</a> placed the song as the third best track of the week, with the senior editor Tom Breihan calling it a monster: "It’s a big, shameless endorphin-rush pop megablast, a riot of synth-bloop hooks and James Brown drum-breaks and house pianos and ecstatic diva-wails.". Breihan also shows surprise with Fergie's rap skills. It was considered the fortieth best song of 2017 by <a href="Rolling%20Stone">Rolling Stone</a>.
Personnel.
Taken from Tidal.
